concept: This research proposes that cortical gamma oscillations may maintain predictive representations through ATP-dependent modulation of parvalbumin-positive interneuron activity. We hypothesize that cellular ATP/ADP ratios could directly influence the temporal stability and synchronization of gamma bursts during predictive coding tasks. This approach may reveal fundamental metabolic constraints on cross-network information maintenance and offers a mechanistic bridge between cellular bioenergetics and cognitive neuroscience.

rationale.statement: Parvalbumin-positive interneurons serve as the primary generators of cortical gamma oscillations through their distinct perisomatic targeting of pyramidal neurons and specialized regulatory properties. These fast-spiking interneurons coordinate synchronized firing patterns essential for gamma rhythm generation, distinguishing them functionally from other interneuron subtypes that target different cellular compartments.

The generation of gamma oscillations represents an exceptionally metabolically demanding process due to the high-frequency firing requirements of parvalbumin-positive interneurons. These cells exhibit elevated basal metabolic rates and substantial energy demands for coordinating communication across cortical and subcortical networks, making them particularly vulnerable to energetic fluctuations.

Cellular ATP/ADP ratios directly regulate interneuron excitability through multiple molecular mechanisms. ATP-dependent ion pumps and channels control membrane potential recovery and firing sustainability, while ADP accumulation impairs potassium channel function and reduces synchronization. AMPK pathways sense these energetic ratios and modulate excitability, establishing a direct cellular link between metabolism and oscillatory capacity.

Metabolic stress consistently disrupts gamma oscillation stability and synchronization through compromised ATP/ADP ratios in energy-sensitive interneurons. Empirical evidence from hypoxia studies and mitochondrial dysfunction models demonstrates that reduced ATP availability directly impairs gamma rhythm generation, confirming the metabolic dependence of these oscillatory networks.

Predictive coding frameworks depend on stable gamma oscillations to maintain internal representations and signal prediction errors effectively. Cognitive tasks relying on predictive coding show performance deficits under metabolic stress, indicating that gamma-band integrity is essential for effective prediction error processing and sensory representation maintenance.

This research approach bridges cellular bioenergetics with cognitive neuroscience by revealing how metabolic constraints fundamentally limit brain function. Investigating ATP/ADP ratio effects on gamma stability offers novel insights into neural resilience mechanisms and provides a mechanistic framework for understanding cognitive performance under physiological stress, surpassing prior approaches that treated metabolism and cognition as separate domains.
